awd_titl_txt: Opportunities to Learn:  Creative Science Through Inquiry, a Middle Grades Teaming Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing opportunities for students to learn creatively in science through inquiry. The project will prepare 72 middle school teachers to work with approximately 1800 students from economically disadvantaged schools who have had few opportunities to participate in technology-rich, inquiry-based learning environments. It will examine coherent sets of experiences through curricular models across mathematics, science, technology and English/language arts so that STEM is collaboratively infused in meaningful, relevant ways into the curriculum throughout the school year. Using a team design, the project will engage university and community college faculty members and industry partners with middle school teachers. Through this effort, teams of educators and experts will develop, test, refine, and infuse STEM principles into regular classroom activities so that students can experience the interconnectedness of STEM through mathematics and science enhanced by technology and technical writing. This project will help address the nations' need to increase the diversity of students entering high school who are better prepared to make course selections that will potentially lead to future STEM careers. 

The project will use a mixed methods design to capture data through questionnaires, focus groups, observations, interviews, videotapes and pre-post tests. Student increases in science achievement and dispositions towards STEM careers will be analyzed using a quasi-experimental design. A propensity score matching process will be used to equate group with sub-group propensity score matching analysis to examine treatment effects by gender, ethnicity, and SES. Repeated measures will be used to examine increases in teacher self-efficacy for teaching science through inquiry and qualitative methods to identify successes and challenges to implementing the collaborative, cross-disciplinary experiences for students. This project will provide a model framework to guide teachers into creating and implementing collaborative STEM lesson units that will engage industry/community college/STEM professionals in the planning, teaching, and evaluating process. Student experiences developed through the framework will expose students to exciting, relevant STEM curriculum that demonstrates the interconnectedness of their academic courses. The enacted model will enhance the teacher teams while building the self-efficacy of the teachers to deliver STEM lessons across the disciplines. Dissemination efforts are two-fold: feedback and community sharing.  Feedback on this model will be garnered through academic presentations from professionals across the STEM disciplines. The project website will also provide access to the framework and sample activities as well as opportunities to react to the model.

por.por_cntn:
Opportunities to Learn: Creative Science Through Inquiry, a Middle Grades Teaming Framework, was a partnership between Mississippi State University’s Department of Curriculum, Instruction and Special Education (CISE), the Office of Research and Economic Development (ORED), and Department of Biological Sciences and with East Mississippi Community College /partnering industries, and Choctaw County, Clay County, Lowndes County, Starkville Oktibbeha, and Winston School Districts. Using a middle school teaming approach, an inquiry-based learning curriculum that cuts across the middle school science, mathematics, technology, and English classrooms was developed.  STEM industry professional aided in integrating STEM industry concepts into the curriculum.

Intellectual Merit: CSI: Mississippi 2.0 curriculum model is built on a framework that STEM education should not be bound by traditional content courses and that early, relevant exposure to STEM career fields is essential to impact K-12 education. Further, STEM research acknowledges that students need to be confident about their skills in mathematics and science before they consider STEM professions. Students must experience STEM concepts through a coherent, relevant curriculum. This STEM curriculum cannot be bounded by traditional courses such as mathematics or science but rather should cut across multiple subjects. While individually these are well established constructs, we designed a framework that supports teachers across mathematics, science, technology, and English/language arts so that STEM is actually collaboratively infused in meaningful, relevant ways into the curriculum throughout the school year. A crucial component of the STEM curriculum is experiences that represent the work of STEM professionals, therefore, undergirding a framework with authentic STEM industry partners which supports teachers and exposes students to the reality of STEM professions.

Over the life of CSI: Mississippi 2.0, teachers participated in Industry fieldtrips where they engaged with STEM professionals in local industries.  Teachers also engaged with workforce development teachers at East Mississippi Community College.  Teachers were given to opportunities to see the integration of work skills and technology in local industries including tire manufacturing, paper pulp production, highly skilled welding (precision skills), development and building of helicopters and airplanes, large engine production, and basic computer programming.  Each of these field trips exposed teachers to a wide array of jobs and skills including jobs that require a high school diploma, work force development training and/or an associate degree, and jobs requiring a bachelor’s degree. 

Broder Impact: Through the life of the project, we provided summer professional development for middle grades teachers using inquiry-based STEM technology lessons integrated across science, mathematics, English/reading.  Teachers were provided explicit instruction on use of the technology and ways to enhance this technology as it related to their course. Lessons were presented with mathematics, science or reading as the primary focus of the lesson while supporting learning in the other subjects.  Once teachers engaged in their own inquiry-based learning, the lessons were decomposed to discuss how the lessons would engage students. Sessions concluded with time for teachers to plan how to implement the inquiry, integrated lessons in their classes

Students in the teachers’ classes both during the life of the project and beyond benefit from broadening the teacher’s knowledge of STEM concepts and technology applications.  Students in these classes experience STEM ideas through inquiry-based learning primarily in their science and mathematics courses.  Students are exposed to the interconnectedness of STEM across the entire curriculum.  Student results indicate that students remained favorable towards pursuing a STEM profession during the middle school years.  This is a significant finding since research suggests that many students lose interest in the middle grades years.
